ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: An introduction to Italian.
How to speak and write in Italian at the elementary level.
I learned some of the fundamentals of the Italian language as well as about Italian culture in a fun, low-stress environment.
learned basics of conversational italian, learned about past and present tense, vocab, grammar
Learning Italian
I began to learn the basic of the italian language, including reading, writing, and speaking.
rudimentary knowledge of the Italian language, basic grammar and conversational skills, minor introduction to the Italian culture.
I learned the basics of Italian language and culture.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Having this class small and everyday helped me stay engaged and I felt like I was truly learning the language.

The course uses a variety of methods to teach Italian (speaking, questions, compositions, projects) which was very well rounded. The pace of the course was just a tad too fast, especially with daily quizzes.

I loved Michael's ITAL 110 class! He really catered the class to our own strengths and weaknesses and facilitated a class where everyone felt comfortable participating. I did have technical issues with the VHL activities for the entire semester, but other than that, I would say just keep doing what you're doing.

this class was really fun and I genuinely looked forward to it everyday. although this is not a class you can get behind on because it met everyday and we had daily quizzes, the work did not feel overwhelming. I wish we had received more feedback throughout the semester because we never got any grades.
Great teacher, great class. Only wish it could have been live

This class was fun, and my professor was charismatic, but I would have been more comfortable if 'homework' assignments were given regularly through the VHL service that we were using. I felt as though there was some ambiguity in what exactly we were supposed to be studying and a more concrete assignment list would have assisted me greatly.

Professor Farina is a the main strength of this specific section. Class was extremely engaging; he makes sure to call on everybody at least once during class. In class, he goes over the workbook exercises and makes sure to call on every single person as we go through the answers. The only fault of this class, which I believe translates to all sections, is the fact that you are essentially teaching yourself. All reading and learning is done prior to class, and class is only used for going over the problems associated with the lesson or addressing any concerns-- if they are brought up.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: There wasn't anything that could have been better.

The small discussion format was incredibly helpful since it really forced us to engage with the material even though it was over Zoom. This format made this class one of the few that was fun to attend and participate in during the pandemic since I felt like I was actually learning.
we were encouraged to talk with our peers outside of class which created a better learning environment despite the isolation of the pandemic.

Our professor was understanding to the unique challenges of the situation and met us halfway, including with a unique way to take the exams. I think that the final project could have been altered somewhat in order to have a more coherent experience.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Especially if you have Micheal Farina, he really makes learning Italian fun!
Yes, anyone who wants to learn Italian should take this course.

Absolutely! Definitely a fun and beautiful language to learn (also easy if you already speak another romance language) in a low-stress environment. There is of course daily reading, weekly compositions, and exams every other week, but this class was one of the few that I truly enjoyed over Zoom (even though it was 7:30 PST)
yes! it was a lot of fun and i learned a lot
Yes

I enjoyed the course, but the ambiguity of the assignments left a little to be desired. Perhaps it would be best to take this course with another professor when it is offered virtually if the structure is an important part of your learning style.

Yes. Only if you are actually interested in the language. Do not take it just because it might be easier than others-- especially if you have previous knowledge with Romance languages. While having prior knowledge will make it more manageable, it will not make the class an easy A. You will still need to put in the work.
I would recommend this course to another student. I believe it does a great job of introducing a new language at a reasonable pace.
